#Text=Solomon Ashkenazi
#Text=Solomon ben Nathan Ashkenazi
#Text=( ca .
#Text=1520-1602 ) was a Jewish physician and businessman active in Ottoman politics during the late 16th century .
#Text=Ashkenazi wielded considerable influence , most famously helping bring about the Jews ’ readmission to Venice in 1573 .
#Text=Early Life and Migration
#Text=Ashkenazi was born in Udine to Jewish parents of German origin .
#Text=He studied medicine at the University of Padua and trained as a rabbi ... [ 1 ]
#Text=Following the expulsion of the Jews from Udine in 1556 , Ashkenazi traveled to Cracow , Poland to serve as chief physician to King Sigismund II Augustus . [ 2 ]
#Text=In 1564 Ashkenazi left for a post as court physician in Istanbul . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=Court Physician in Istanbul
#Text=In Istanbul Ashkenazi rose to prominence , befriending the Venetian Bailo Marcantonio Barbaro and the Ottoman Grand Vizier Mehmed Sokollu . [ 2 ]
#Text=He and his brother also became involved in the wine trade between Crete and Poland , centered in Istanbul , as did many Jews of the time . [ 5 ]
#Text=The outbreak of the Ottoman-Venetian War in 1570 turned Ashkenazi into a key intermediary party between Turkey and Venice . [ 6 ]
#Text=Ashkenazi held two posts during the war : royal physician to Sokollu ’s wife and official physician to the Venetian community in Istanbul .
#Text=He carried out secret orders from the Grand Vizier intended to bring about peace , preventing arrests of military leaders and carrying messages between the two sides .
#Text=Together with the Grand Dragoman Ali Bey , Ashkenazi drafted the peace treaty that ended the war in 1573 . [ 3 ] [ 7 ] [ 8 ]
#Text=Ashkenazi was instrumental in choosing a successor for the Polish King Sigismund II Augustus , who left no heir upon his death in 1572 .
#Text=Polish law required an election be held .
#Text=The candidates included the Russian tsar Ivan the Terrible ; the German emperor Maximilian II ; the Pope ’s nominee , a minor Catholic prince ; and the French prince , Henri of Anjou .
#Text=The entire Europe balance of power was in limbo .
#Text=Despite ostensibly belonging to the Polish gentry , the choice of the next Polish king effectively rested in the hands of the Ottoman Porte , whose sphere of influence extended into Poland .
#Text=A French ambassador traveled to Istanbul to win the endorsement of Turkish leaders .
#Text=He met with Ashkenazi , convincing him a French king of Poland was necessary to maintain the balance of power ; in turn , Ashkenazi persuaded the Grand Vizier to back Henri .

#Text=After Henri ascended the Polish throne , Ashkenazi sent the king his congratulations , writing , “ I have rendered your majesty most important service in securing your election : I have effected all that was done here . ” [ 9 ]
#Text=Readmission of Venetian Jews

#Text=In 1572 , the Venetian Doge , Alvise I Mocenigo , called for the re-enforcement of the 1556 decree of expulsion , inciting many Jews to leave and igniting a contentious debate in the Senate . [ 2 ]
#Text=The Jews ’ involvement in foreign trade and pawn-broking made them vital economic assets to the Venetian city-state .
#Text=Moreover , some Venetian citizens objected morally to the replacement of Jewish banks with the Christian Monte di Pietà , an up-and-coming institution in Venetian towns .
#Text=At the same time , others argued that Jewish expulsion was a matter of moral necessity , citing the banishment of Jews from Spain and Portugal . [ 10 ]
#Text=Back in Istanbul , Ashkenazi used his contacts to exert political pressure on the Venetian authorities on the issue of Jewish expulsion . [ 11 ]
#Text=Through an arrangement with Jacopo Soranzo , a Venetian official in Istanbul , Ashkenazi had arranged for some expelled Venetian Jews to come to Turkey .
#Text=Soranzo returned to Venice shortly afterward to warn the Senate of the threat inherent in that arrangement .
#Text=The Jews living presently in Turkey , he explained , who had been expelled earlier from Spain and Portugal , now manufactured weapons for the Ottoman forces to use against Venice .
#Text=To add onto them Jews expelled from Venice could be costly or even dangerous .
#Text=Ashkenazi made similar arguments to Barbaro , who relayed them to the Doge in his dispatches on the Ottoman situation [ 12 ]
#Text=These factors doubtless contributed to the Senate ’s decision to readmit the Jews in December 1573 .
#Text=But it would be fallacious to attribute full credit to Ashkenazi .
#Text=Another proposal presented to the Venetian Senate earlier that year suggested the Jews expelled from Spain and Portugal be permitted entry , provided they lived in ghettos .
#Text=While that proposal did not pass , it served to remind the Senate of the economic importance of the Jews and likely contributed to their ultimate readmission [ 13 ]
#Text=Ambassador to Venice
#Text=Following the Polish election , the Porte named Ashkenazi envoy to Venice .
#Text=Controversy flamed on both sides about the appointment of a Jew .
#Text=In Turkey , Sokollu vouched for the doctor ’s political acumen , while in Venice Barbaro sung Ashkenazi ’s praises . [ 9 ]
#Text=After some debate , Ashkenazi won the seat and travelled to Venice in May 1574 . [ 14 ]
#Text=The Venetian authorities and Jewish community showered Ashkenazi with gifts upon his arrival . [ 9 ]
#Text=As Ottoman ambassador , his track record proved mixed .
#Text=Ashkenazi successfully negotiated a dispute over the borders of Dalmatia , [ 15 ] but failed in his advocacy for the formation of a Venetian-Ottoman military alliance . [ 3 ]
#Text=While in Venice he also helped a group of Jewish merchants petition for compensation for the property they lost after leaving Venice because of the banishment decree .
#Text=The petition succeeded and the merchants were compensated ; many nonetheless chose not to return to Venice [ 16 ]
#Text=Return to Istanbul and Death
#Text=Ashkenazi returned to Istanbul in July 1574 , remaining active in politics until Sokollu ’s death in 1579 .
#Text=He managed his financial affairs poorly and died in poverty in 1602 [ 17 ]
